title: Soldier's family outraged by Scottish politician’s ‘freedom fighters’ comments
text:
Play video The family of a soldier murdered by the IRA in Belfast say they are outraged by a member of the Scottish National Parliament described the IRA killers as "Freedom Fighters".
The MSP made the comments on Twitter in response to a request for his support for a campaign for justice following the murder of three Scottish soldiers in Belfast 45 years ago.
Royal Highland Fusiliers Dougald McCaughey and brothers John and Joseph McCaig, ages 23, 17 and 18, were off-duty when they were lured out of a Belfast City Centre bar and murdered by the IRA in March 1971.
The three men were taken to a remote location in north Belfast and shot dead.
The commanding officer had to identify their bodies.
Last week SNP politician John Mason was asked on Twitter to support a campaign seeking justice for the soldiers.
The member of the Scottish Parliament replied saying: "You say Irish murderers. Others say Irish freedom fighters."
John Mason @JohnMasonMSP Follow @ albion_rover You say Irish murderers. Others say Irish freedom fighters. I support Scottish soldiers if they do good but not if they do bad
22:35 - 30 Jan 2017 Retweet Reply Favourite Later Mr Mason said his comments were general and not meant to cause any offence, but it's his failure to apologise to the families which has caused anger.
John Mason @JohnMasonMSP Follow I have been asked to clarify that my comments were general and not about any specific case. I certainly did not intend to cause any offence.
19:09 - 1 Feb 2017 Retweet Reply Favourite A relative of Dougald McCaughey says the comments are adding to his family's pain.
David McCaughey said: “I can’t understand his comments, I think what the man says is deplorable, he has not actually thought the families have feelings, regarding what happened to the boys back in 1971.
“This was three boys out for the day, time off from their job serving in Northern ireland and they were lured into a honey trap, came to a hillside outside Belfast and murdered by the IRA.”
No-one has ever been convicted of the murders.
Moves are underway to raise the funding to get the lawyers behind the successful Omagh bombing private prosecution to bring a legal action.
A memorial was erected to the three soldiers in Ligoneil in north Belfast but it has been attacked a number of times.
